page.title: 11"Bowcombe"-Local Issues 2
page.content: From the point of view of inhabitants of the area other than farmers, one burning issue; quite literally, is that of the old practice of farmers of burning the corn stubble after the crop has been harvested. Not only does this yield all the dangers normally associated with fire and smoke, and on a large scale, but there is also an aftermath which is not always realised: that of fine black ash which, born on the wind; "can cover every surface in a house and a garden, even into the furthest recesses, and is extremely difficult to remove". {Another vital issue of contemporary {national concern is that of the use by {farmers of chemical fertilisers and {insecticides, and aerial spraying in {particular. Some fear that there may {be unforeseen effects upon health.}
